definition[0]: to climb up, down, or over something quickly and with difficulty, especially using your hands to help you
example[0]: They tried to scramble up the cliff.
example[1]: She scrambled down the tree as quickly as she could.
definition[1]: to move somewhere in a hurried awkward way
example[2]: Alan scrambled out of the way.
example[3]: Micky scrambled to his feet  (=stood up very quickly and awkwardly) and hurried into the kitchen.
definition[2]: to try to do something difficult very quickly
example[4]: They were scrambling to give the impression that the situation was under control.
definition[3]: to struggle or compete with other people to get or reach something
example[5]: Thousands of people will be scrambling for tickets.
definition[4]: to use special equipment to mix messages, radio signals etc into a different form, so that they cannot be understood by other people without the correct equipment
example[6]: Our conversation will be electronically scrambled.
definition[5]: to mix words, ideas, sentences etc so that they are not in the right order and do not make sense
example[7]: The words in each sentence are scrambled.
definition[6]: if a military plane scrambles, it goes up into the air very quickly in order to escape or to attack an enemy
definition[7]: a difficult climb in which you have to use your hands to help you
example[8]: The village was a 20-minute scramble away.
definition[8]: a situation in which people compete with and push each other in order to get what they want
example[9]: the usual scramble for the bathroom every morning
example[10]: a scramble to carry the baggage into the house
definition[9]: a situation in which something has to be done very quickly, with a lot of rushing around
example[11]: It was a mad scramble trying to get things ready in time.
definition[10]: a motorcycle race over rough ground
